Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content:
@jansako - Today at 5:57 AM
`those are not good examples. Intel or Nvidia is not going to be running their hardware before it starts selling it (I don't know if Bitmain does or does not). Still think a clear and concise statement from the KMD team would go a long way. Just to address the 'why'.`
1) the instant you make your anti-ASIC case about a single company and not about ASICs, you've already lost any validity your case might have.
2) Why should there be a "why" statement about nothing changing?

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: 3) In your theory that the algo should change to prevent BM from silently mining on their own, what's to prevent them from adding RAM, mining on their own, and then never releasing just to spite the assholes who changed 2 variables in an attempt to financially hurt BM?

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: I've yet to see a single coin make an anti-ASIC change to 144,5 (or any other K & N values) that the majority of the reason wasn't just a bunch of "fuk Shitmain" and not much else

Content: I can *almost* see the "well, equihash was meant to be anti ASIC" claim, but even that falls flat because it's still the same thing - it's all about RAM cost

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: a $1.5M+ cost to market, do people really believe that ASIC makers are just going to say "oh well, we lost on that one; just scrap it all" as opposed to, worst case, spending $90k to add RAM and private mine to recoup their losses?

Content: imo, the move to exclude all AMD miners, and pretty much anyone with an NVIDIA older than a 1050, is pure insanity

Author: ComputerGenie#2331
Content: especially when the claim is usually "everyone has a GPU".... Guess what, Skippy, "everyone" doesn't have $1k per to drop on a high-end GPU that is 2+ years old and costs more than when it was released
